description: Borrowed from French brassard, from bras (“arm”). The form brasset is attested since at least 1676 (Scots brassat is attested since 1590); brassart since at least 1736, brassard since at least 1788.

entries.meaning: (historical) An item of plate armor that protects the arm.
An insignia or band worn around the upper arm.
examples: Muslims found not wearing the white brassards as prescribed by the army were simply despatched on the spot.
